verdict.summary: A fetch request was aborted, typically via an AbortController signal timeout or explicit abort call.

dead_ends.action: Catching the error and retrying immediately without checking if the abort was intentional
dead_ends.why_fails: If the abort was triggered by a timeout or user action, retrying immediately will likely be aborted again or create duplicate requests

dead_ends.action: Removing the AbortController to avoid the error
dead_ends.why_fails: Without abort control, requests hang indefinitely on slow or unresponsive servers, causing resource leaks

workarounds.action: Increase the AbortSignal timeout for slow endpoints
workarounds.how: Use AbortSignal.timeout(30000) instead of the default, or create a custom AbortController with a longer setTimeout
workarounds.condition: when the server is slow but eventually responds

workarounds.action: Implement retry logic with exponential backoff for transient failures
workarounds.how: Check if error.name === 'AbortError' and retry with increasing delays: 1s, 2s, 4s, up to a max retry count
workarounds.condition: when the abort is caused by transient network issues

leads_to.condition: when the server forcibly closes the connection during abort

preceded_by.condition: when DNS delays trigger the abort timeout

frequently_confused_with.distinction: AbortError means the client intentionally cancelled the request via AbortController, while ECONNRESET means the server or network dropped the connection unexpectedly
